title: Beta-Blockers for Migraine
author: Keri Wiginton

content: A medication that is used to treat high blood pressure can lessen serious headaches for some people. These drugs are called beta-blockers.

Tell your doctor if your headaches or other migraine symptoms aren’t well-controlled. Fewer than half of people who need preventive medication get the treatment they need. There’s no cure, but there are lots of ways to manage migraine attacks. Your health care team can help you figure out if beta-blockers are right for you.

content_blocks.text: A medication that is used to treat high blood pressure can lessen serious headaches for some people. These drugs are called beta-blockers.

Tell your doctor if your headaches or other migraine symptoms aren’t well-controlled. Fewer than half of people who need preventive medication get the treatment they need. There’s no cure, but there are lots of ways to manage migraine attacks. Your health care team can help you figure out if beta-blockers are right for you.

sections.heading: What Are Beta-Blockers?
content: They’re drugs that block the effects of epinephrine, or adrenaline. That’s a hormone your body sends out when you’re stressed, scared, or excited. Beta-blockers relax blood vessels and slow your heart rate. That lessens how hard your heart has to work and makes it easier for your blood to flow.
There are different kinds of beta-blockers. None were originally designed to treat headaches . But two are approved for migraine:
There’s less evidence to support the use of other beta-blockers for migraine. But your doctor might use certain ones “off-label” to treat your headaches, including:

sections.heading: How Do Beta-Blockers Help Migraine?
content: These drugs won’t stop a migraine after it starts. Instead, they’re used to ward off future attacks. Your doctor may call that prophylaxis treatment. Scientists figured this out by accident in the late 1960s.

It’s not clear how beta-blockers help with migraine. Experts think several things are going on. One theory is they block a process called cortical spreading depression . That’s a set of changes in the brain that may trigger a migraine.
Beta-blockers may also:
bullets: Affect certain brain chemicals, mainly serotonin

It’s not clear how beta-blockers help with migraine. Experts think several things are going on. One theory is they block a process called cortical spreading depression . That’s a set of changes in the brain that may trigger a migraine.
Beta-blockers may also:
associated_bullets: Affect certain brain chemicals, mainly serotonin

sections.heading: Who Should Take Beta-Blockers for Migraine?
content: Most scientific research shows that beta-blockers are a good way to treat episodic migraines -- fewer than four headaches a month. But your doctor may still want you to give them a try if you have chronic migraine. That’s when you have at least 15 headache days a month.

content: Your migraine management plan depends on several things. That includes how often you have headaches, how serious your symptoms are, and what kind of medicine you’ve tried in the past. Your overall quality of life matters, too.

content_blocks.text: Your migraine management plan depends on several things. That includes how often you have headaches, how serious your symptoms are, and what kind of medicine you’ve tried in the past. Your overall quality of life matters, too.

content: Here are some questions your doctor may ask to decide if you need preventive treatment:
Your doctor might lean toward beta-blockers right off the bat if you have certain medical conditions, such as:
bullets: Do migraine symptoms make it hard to go to work or socialize?
Do you have four or more headaches a month?
How often do you take  acute, or “rescue,” treatments?
Do your headaches last more than three days?

content_blocks.text: Here are some questions your doctor may ask to decide if you need preventive treatment:
associated_bullets: Do migraine symptoms make it hard to go to work or socialize?
Do you have four or more headaches a month?
How often do you take  acute, or “rescue,” treatments?
Do your headaches last more than three days?

content_blocks.text: Your doctor might lean toward beta-blockers right off the bat if you have certain medical conditions, such as:

sections.heading: How Do You Take Beta-Blockers for Migraine?
content: There’s lots of evidence to show that, when taken every day, beta-blockers are a good way to lessen future headaches by at least half. And if you do have a migraine attack, it may be shorter and less severe.
Your doctor may start you off on a short-acting dose that you take two times a day. If that goes well, they may switch you to one long-acting pill later on.

content_blocks.text: There’s lots of evidence to show that, when taken every day, beta-blockers are a good way to lessen future headaches by at least half. And if you do have a migraine attack, it may be shorter and less severe.
Your doctor may start you off on a short-acting dose that you take two times a day. If that goes well, they may switch you to one long-acting pill later on.

content: Drugs for migraine prevention , including beta-blockers, may not help right away. You’ll likely need to wait at least 8 weeks to see if there's any improvement. But tell your doctor sooner if you don’t feel any better. They may need to change your dose or add another migraine drug.

Be open about any of your lingering symptoms. Your doctor can give you medication for breakthrough headaches even if you’re on preventive treatment. Lifestyle changes or other therapies may also help.

sections.heading: Who Shouldn’t Take Beta-Blockers?
content: Your doctor will go over all the pros and cons of your treatment choices. But they’re unlikely to prescribe beta-blockers if you have certain health conditions, including:
Other conditions that might make beta-blockers a no-go include:

Tell your doctor if you have active depression. They’ll want to keep a close eye on how you feel after you start a beta-blocker. These drugs don’t usually cause mood issues, but you may feel a little down when you take them.
bullets: Heart rhythm problems like AV-block or sick sinus syndrome
Low blood pressure when you stand up

associated_bullets: Heart rhythm problems like AV-block or sick sinus syndrome

sections.heading: Do Beta-Blockers Have Side Effects?
content: They’re generally considered safe. But like all drugs, they may cause some unwanted symptoms.
Common side effects include:
Less common side effects include:
Bring up any symptoms that bother you. You may need to change your dose or switch to a different treatment.
bullets: Swelling in your hands and feet

content_blocks.text: They’re generally considered safe. But like all drugs, they may cause some unwanted symptoms.

associated_bullets: Swelling in your hands and feet

content_blocks.text: Bring up any symptoms that bother you. You may need to change your dose or switch to a different treatment.

sections.heading: What if You Want to Stop Beta-Blockers?
content: There may come a time when you want to stop your medication. But you could have heart rate or blood pressure problems if you stop taking beta-blockers all of a sudden.
Always talk to your doctor before you make any changes to your treatment. They’ll help you stop or switch to another medication safely.

sources: Sirisha Sanamandra, MD, Yale Medicine; assistant professor of clinical neurology, Yale School of Medicine.
American Family Physician : “Medications for Migraine Prophylaxis.”
American Migraine Foundation: “Migraine Prevention 101: What It Is, When To Use It and Why.”
Neurotherapeutics : “Current Prophylactic Medications for Migraine and Their Potential Mechanisms of Action.”
PLoS One : “Beta-blockers for the prevention of headache in adults, a systematic review and meta-analysis.”
Clinical and Translational Neuroscience : “Treatment of migraine attacks and prevention of migraine: Guidelines by the German Migraine and Headache Society and the German Society of Neurology.”
Continuum (American Academy of Neurology) : “Preventive Migraine Treatment.”
meta_description: Beta-blockers are used to treat high blood pressure and other conditions, but they can also help with migraines. Learn how they work and if they might be right for you.
